course.notes: This course includes an academic civic engagement (ACE) component.
course.title: Community Applications of Psychology

course.description: Students explore the religious significance of selected works of literature and examine how literary plot, character, symbolism, and theme raise religious questions, reveal ethical concerns and imply theological convictions. Offered periodically.
course.name: Religion & Literature
course.title: Religion and Literature

course.description: This intensive January term course empowers students to design a career path rooted in self-awareness and adaptability. Through a blend of introspective exercises, hands-on workshops, and real-world simulations, participants uncover their core values, strengths, and passions while learning to articulate their unique value in the evolving business and professional landscapes. Not open to first year students. Prerequisite: sophomore standing or above.
course.name: Business Career Compass
course.notes: Not open to first-year students.

course.description: This course gives students the opportunity to work on real world physics and engineering problems. Companies, non-profits, and other organizations provide projects relevant and important to the organizations' goals. Students work in teams to approach these projects from an engineering design perspective that emphasizes hands-on work, prototyping, and organizational skills. Offered annually during January Term. Prerequisite: PHYS 244 or permission of the instructor.
course.name: Engineering Design Pract
course.prerequisites: PHYS 244 or permission of the instructor.
course.title: Engineering Design Practicum

course.description: This practical course provides information needed for informed decision making in major areas of personal finance, including budgeting, basic tax planning, insurance, investments, major purchases and retirement planning. Offered during January Term. Does not count toward the finance or management area of emphasis within economics major, or the management studies concentration. Prerequisite: sophomore standing or above.
course.name: Personal Finance
course.notes: Not open to first-year students.

course.description: Students study topics in biology. Topics vary from year to year at the discretion of the department. Class work depends on the topics and instructor, but is consistent with the amount and level of work in other 200-level biology courses. May be repeated if topics are different. Counts as an elective toward biology major. May count toward other majors or concentrations if approved by the chair of that major/concentration. Offered periodically each term. Prerequisites: vary.
course.name: Top: Fly Fishing Entomology

revisions.name: Top: Topics in Biology
revisions.notes: Prerequisite: BIO 150

course.title: Topics in Biology

course.description: Teams of science, engineering, nursing, and economics students research the potential for commercialization of a novel medical technology. Students gain experience with medical procedures, market research, the FDA approval process, financial analysis, the health insurance industry, business ethics, intellectual property law, and human subjects research ethics. At the end of this practicum, students write a business plan and deliver a professional presentation of their recommendations to staff at the partner company, investment group, or medical organization. Offered annually during January Term. Does not count toward biology major. Prerequisite: permission of instructor.
course.name: Biomedical Innovation Scholars Prog
course.title: Biomedical Innovation Scholars Program

course.description: Students continue learning Spanish in an intercultural context. The course continues to examine the Spanish-speaking world through exploration of topics, for example: cities and urban life; housing; and the historical roots of culinary traditions and food production. In-class speaking, listening, reading, and writing activities are complemented by attendance at two required culture tables. Offered each semester and January Term. Does not count toward Spanish major. Prerequisite: SPAN 111 or placement into SPAN 112.
course.name: Intro Spanish Language/World II
course.notes: Prerequisite: SPAN 111 or placement recommendation.
course.title: Introduction to Spanish Language and the Spanish-Speaking World II

course.description: The creators in this class transgress the boundaries of gender, genre, and form. Their works tell women’s stories from intersectional perspectives and many emphasize biography, autobiography, or history. However, they also hybridize, mashup, and cross genres and forms. For example, Laura Esquivel’s Like Water for Chocolate is both a novel and a cookbook while Ntozake Shange describes When the Rainbow Is Enuf, which combines poetry, dance, and music, as a "choreopoem." Students will examine the role of the female writer, director, and artist in texts from across cultures. By analyzing how they defy cultural constructs like genre, form, gender, nation, and race, students will appreciate how the texts reveal and redress cultural differences shaped by power, privilege, and inequality.
course.name: Top: Herstory: Playing with Genre
course.title: Topics in Cross-Cultural Literature

course.description: This course considers masterworks of Russian and Soviet cinema that were directed by women. In what subtle and/or overt ways did being socialized as a woman affect a director's perspective? In what subtle and/or overt ways are the challenges that women faced in the USSR and in contemporary Russia reflected in their films? Topics include basic cinema analysis, Russian cinema criticism, Russian film theory, and gender theory.
course.name: Russian Film Directed by Women
course.title: Soviet and Russian Film Directed by Women

course.description: Big History examines patterns across vast time scales, from cosmic origins to the present. Students trace the brain's story from the evolution of the simplest nervous systems to hominin brain evolution to contemporary neuroscience. This interdisciplinary course integrates evolutionary biology, history and philosophy of psychology, literature, and the arts to explore how different cultures and eras have conceptualized the brain and mind. Through primary sources, scientific papers, creative works, and computational visualization, students examine the brain from its evolutionary origins to its function as the biological foundation of human culture and society. Prerequisite: PSYCH 125.
course.name: Top: A Big History of the Brain
course.notes: Full topic title: A Big History of the Brain: Past, Present, and Imagined
Futures
course.title: Topics in Psychology

course.description: Have you ever wondered why exercise makes your tissues stronger? This course offers an accessible introduction to the principles governing the structure and adaptation of the musculoskeletal system. We will explore how physical forces influence the health and function of our most critical tissues, including bone, cartilage, tendon, and muscle. The curriculum will bridge the gap between cellular mechanisms (known as mechanobiology) and whole-body function, demonstrating how an understanding of mechanical loading can optimize performance and accelerate recovery. This is a foundational course perfect for those in physical science majors and/or considering careers in the rehabilitation sciences, medicine, or fitness.
course.name: Top: Intro to Tissue Adaptation
course.notes: Full topic Title: Forces that Shape Us: Introduction to Tissue Adaptation
This course is open only to seniors, juniors and sophomores.
course.title: Topics in Kinesiology

course.description: In this two-course sequence students learn the basics of ancient Greek. By studying the language's vocabulary, grammar, and syntax, they not only gain appreciation for its intricacies and nuances but also learn more about their own language and about language in general. Completion of both GREEK 111 and GREEK 112 equips students to translate almost any ancient Greek text with the aid of a dictionary. Offered annually in the fall semester.
course.name: Beginning Greek I

course.description: In this course, popular myths, slurs, and mythologies around images of Voodoo religion are examined through histories of the African diaspora and interpretations of religion and cultural contact in Black Atlantic studies. While providing students with a fundamental understanding of African Diaspora Traditions such as Conjure (USA), Vodou (Haiti), Obeah, Kumina, Revival Zion and Rastari (Jamaica), Spiritual Baptist (Tobago), and Yoruba (USA & Cuba), media and film representations of Haitian Vodou and Voodoo in the Lower South are central sites of investigation. Viewing and analyzing horror films such White Zombie (1932) and animated features such as Princess and the Frog (2009), we work toward a historical description of how the making of world religions, race, media & representation, and consumer capitalism shaped the ways audiences in North America have come to think and talk about Voodoo.
course.name: Top: African Diaspora Religion
course.notes: Full topic title: voodoo, Hoodoo, and Hollywood: African Diaspora Religion in
the Americas
course.title: Topics in Religion

course.description: Students study how a particular religious tradition (or traditions) interacts with a specific topic. Topics vary, but possibilities include the environment, peace and violence, technology, or sexuality. The topic orients students to important questions about how the particular religious tradition understands and acts in the world, as well as debates about what counts as religion. May be repeated if the topic is different.
course.name: Top: Creation: An Am Indian Ethos
course.title: Topics in Religion

course.description: Nordic sagas and modern fantastic works pose important theological questions such as the nature of reality in fantasy, the Eucharist, honor, gift, the grotesque, evil, salvation in Christ, and life as a quest and pilgrimage. They also raise valuable problems about the relationship of Christian beliefs to cultural narratives. Students may read J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings, G.K. Chesterton, and selected sagas, alongside theological writings. Offered periodically during January Term.
course.name: Tolkien and Theology

course.description: This course is an introduction to modern and postmodern art and thought after World War II through a survey of painting, sculpture, and new-media arts. Students learn about celebrated art and artists, major values such as issues of identity informing their work, and ways of analyzing and making sense of newer art. Offered annually. Prerequisite: none, but at least one college art history or studio art course is recommended.
course.name: Art Since 1945
course.prerequisites: none, but at least one college art history or studio art course is recommended.

course.description: The field of chemistry is constantly expanding into new frontiers. This course provides an in-depth study of special topics that are chosen with attention to student interest and available staff. Topics are announced prior to registration for the term; see the current class and lab schedule. May be repeated if topic is different. Offered periodically.
course.name: Top: Organic Spectroscopy
course.title: Selected Topics in Chemistry

course.description: The field of chemistry is constantly expanding into new frontiers. This course provides an in-depth study of special topics that are chosen with attention to student interest and available staff. Topics are announced prior to registration for the term; see the current class and lab schedule. May be repeated if topic is different. Offered periodically.
course.name: Top: Solid State Chemistry
course.title: Selected Topics in Chemistry

course.description: There are vaccines to prevent more than 20 life-threatening diseases, helping people to live longer, healthier lives. Despite controversy, vaccines remain a necessary tool to continue to protect and improve the health of populations. This course explores the basics of vaccinology, how vaccines are licensed and recommended, the vaccine safety system in the U.S., how vaccines are used to prevent and control disease, the factors influencing vaccine hesitancy, and strategies to strengthen vaccine confidence. Offered periodically in January term.
course.name: Vaccines

course.description: Using methods from public health and literary studies, students critically analyze the role of storytelling in medical encounters. In reflection papers and close-readings, students ask how memoir, film, and poetry highlight the layers of meaning and power dynamics that doctors and patients navigate. Students also volunteer with community partners to create quilts and bandages for hospitals and package them with other medical supplies, telling their own stories about the experience. Offered periodically in January term. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Medical Humanities Narratives
course.notes: This course includes an academic civic engagement (ACE) component.
course.title: Medical Humanities: Narrative Analysis

course.description: This course examines the relationship of psychoanalysis to critical social theory. Students are introduced to classic psychoanalytic texts and works in critical theory that creatively take up or challenge them. Students are encouraged to develop their own perspectives on ethical issues surrounding human subjectivity, gender and sexuality, race and coloniality, and the possibility of progress -- as well as debates about psychoanalysis as an agent of oppressive normalization versus a force for liberatory social change. Offered periodically in January term. Prerequisite: WRIT 120 or equivalent.
course.name: Psychoanalysis and Critical Theory
course.notes: Not open to first-year students.

course.description: This course provides a comprehensive research opportunity, including an introduction to relevant background material, technical instruction, identification of a meaningful project, and data collection. The topic is determined by the faculty member in charge of the course and may relate to his/her research interests. Offered at the discretion of the department. May be offered as a 1.00 credit course or .50 credit course. Prerequisite: determined by individual instructor.
course.name: Research: Spectroscopy of Surfaces
course.notes: Registration by application.
course.title: Directed Undergraduate Research
